image.caption: Image
image.description: The container image used as a template to run the container.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels associated to the container.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The container name.

network_driver.caption: Network Driver
network_driver.description: The network driver used by the container. For example, bridge, overlay, host, none, etc.

orchestrator.caption: Orchestrator
orchestrator.description: The orchestrator managing the container, such as ECS, EKS, K8s, or OpenShift.

pod_uuid.caption: Pod UUID
pod_uuid.description: The unique identifier of the pod (or equivalent) that the container is executing on.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

runtime.caption: Runtime
runtime.description: The backend running the container, such as containerd or cri-o.

size.caption: Size
size.description: The size of the container image.

@deprecated.message: Use the labels or tags attribute instead.

tag.caption: Image Tag
tag.description: The tag used by the container. It can indicate version, format, OS.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the container.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The full container unique identifier for this instantiation of the container. For example: ac2ea168264a08f9aaca0dfc82ff3551418dfd22d02b713142a6843caa2f61bf.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.
container.name: container

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.description: The CVSS object details Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores from the advisory that are related to the vulnerability.

cwe.caption: CWE
cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.

cwe_uid.caption: CWE UID
cwe_uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) unique identifier. For example: CWE-787.

cwe_url.caption: CWE URL
cwe_url.description: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) definition URL. For example: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: A brief description of the CVE Record.

epss.caption: EPSS
epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

references.caption: References
references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the CVE Record.

related_cwes.caption: Related CWEs
related_cwes.description: Describes the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) details related to the CVE Record.

title.caption: Title
title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the CVE record.

type.caption: Vulnerability Type
type.description:
The vulnerability type as selected from a large dropdown menu during CVE refinement.

Most frequently used vulnerability types are: DoS, Code Execution, Overflow, Memory Corruption, Sql Injection, XSS, Directory Traversal, Http Response Splitting, Bypass something, Gain Information, Gain Privileges, CSRF, File Inclusion. For more information see Vulnerabilities By Type distributions.

uid.caption: CVE ID
uid.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

cve.caption: CVE
cve.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) object represents publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities defined in CVE Program catalog (CVE). There is one CVE Record for each vulnerability in the catalog.
cve.name: cve

base_score.caption: Base Score
base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.

depth.caption: CVSS Depth
depth.description: The CVSS depth represents a depth of the equation used to calculate CVSS score.

metrics.caption: Metrics
metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: { {"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.

overall_score.caption: Overall Score
overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

severity.caption: Severity
severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 – 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 – 6.9)
  • High (7.0 – 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The source URL for the CVSS score. For example: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44228

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

vector_string.caption: Vector String
vector_string.description: The CVSS vector string is a text representation of a set of CVSS metrics. It is commonly used to record or transfer CVSS metric information in a concise form. For example: 3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:H.

vendor_name.caption: Vendor Name
vendor_name.description: The vendor that provided the CVSS score. For example: NVD, REDHAT etc.

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) object provides a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity.
cvss.name: cvss

category.description: The name of the data classification category that data matched into, e.g. Financial, Personal, Governmental, etc.

category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the data classification category.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Personal
1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.

2.caption: Governmental
2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.

3.caption: Financial
3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.

4.caption: Business
4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.

5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement
5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.

6.caption: Security
6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.

classifier_details.description: Describes details about the classifier used for data classification.

data_lifecycle_state.caption: Data Lifecycle State
data_lifecycle_state.description: The name of the stage or state that the data was in. E.g., Data-at-Rest, Data-in-Transit, etc.

data_lifecycle_state_id.caption: Data Lifecycle State ID
data_lifecycle_state_id.description: The stage or state that the data was in when it was assessed or scanned by a data security tool.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The data lifecycle state is unknown.

1.caption: Data at-Rest
1.description: The data was stored on physical or logical media and was not actively moving through the network nor was being processed. E.g., data stored in a database, PDF files in a file share, or EHR records in object storage.

2.caption: Data in-Transit
2.description: The data was actively moving through the network or from one physical or logical location to another. E.g., emails being send, data replication or Change Data Capture (CDC) streams, or sensitive data processed on an API.

3.caption: Data in-Use
3.description: The data was being processed, accessed, or read by a system, making it active in memory or CPU. E.g., sensitive data in a Business Intelligence tool, ePHI being processed in an EHR application or a user viewing data stored in a spreadsheet or PDF.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The data lifecycle state is not mapped. See the data_lifecycle_state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

detection_pattern.caption: Detection Pattern
detection_pattern.description: Specific pattern, algorithm, fingerprint, or model used for detection.

detection_system.caption: Detection System
detection_system.description: The name of the type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from. E.g., Endpoint, Secure Email Gateway, etc.

detection_system_id.caption: Detection System ID
detection_system_id.description: The type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the detection_system attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Endpoint
1.description: A dedicated agent or sensor installed on a device, either a dedicated data security tool or an Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Symantec DLP, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MDE).

10.caption: Application-Level DLP
10.description: A built in Data Loss Prevention (DLP) or other data security capability within a tool or platform such as an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) or Customer Relations Management (CRM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.

11.caption: Developer Security
11.description: Any Developer Security tool such as an Infrastructure-as-Code (IAC) security scanner, Secrets Detection, or Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SSDLC) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., TruffleHog, GitGuardian, Git-Secrets.

12.caption: Data Security Posture Management
12.description: A Data Security Posture Management (DSPM) tool is a continuous monitoring and data discovery solution that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies for local and cloud environments. E.g., Cyera, Sentra, IBM Polar Security.

2.caption: DLP Gateway
2.description: A Data Loss Prevention (DLP) gateway that is positioned in-line of an information store such as a network share, a database, or otherwise that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.

3.caption: Mobile Device Management
3.description: A Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on mobile devices (e.g., cellphones, tablets, End User Devices [EUDs]).

4.caption: Data Discovery & Classification
4.description: A tool that actively identifies and classifies sensitive data in digital media and information stores in accordance with a policy or automated functionality. E.g, Amazon Macie, Microsoft Purview.

5.caption: Secure Web Gateway
5.description: A Secure Web Gateway (SWG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies at a network-edge such as within a proxy or firewall service.

6.caption: Secure Email Gateway
6.description: A Secure Email Gateway (SEG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies within email systems. E.g., Microsoft Defender for Office, Google Workspaces.

7.caption: Digital Rights Management
7.description: A Digital Rights Management (DRM) or a dedicated Information Rights Management (IRM) are tools which can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on digital media via policy or user access rights.

8.caption: Cloud Access Security Broker
8.description: A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies in-line to cloud systems such as the public cloud or Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) tool. E.g., Forcepoint CASB, SkyHigh Security.

9.caption: Database Activity Monitoring
9.description: A Database Activity Monitoring (DAM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies as part of a dedicated database or warehouse monitoring solution.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of detection system or a multi-variate system made up of several other systems.

endpoint.description: The Endpoint object describes a physical or virtual device that connects to and exchanges information with a computer network. Some examples of endpoints are mobile devices, desktop computers, virtual machines, embedded devices, and servers. Internet-of-Things devices—like cameras, lighting, refrigerators, security systems, smart speakers, and thermostats—are also endpoints.

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: A numerical response status code providing details about the connection.

network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint
network_endpoint.description: Provides characteristics of the network endpoint.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

created_time.description: The time when the enrichment data was generated.

data.description: The enrichment data associated with the attribute and value. The meaning of this data depends on the type the enrichment record.

raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

short_desc.description: A short description of the enrichment data.

src_url.description: The URL of the source of the enrichment data.

type.description: The enrichment type. For example: location.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

value.caption: Value
value.description: The value of the attribute to which the enriched data pertains.

enrichment.caption: Enrichment
enrichment.description: The Enrichment object provides inline enrichment data for specific attributes of interest within an event. It serves as a mechanism to enhance or supplement the information associated with the event by adding additional relevant details or context.
enrichment.name: enrichment

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the environment variable.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

value.caption: Value
value.description: The value of the environment variable.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The timestamp indicating when the EPSS score was calculated.

percentile.caption: EPSS Percentile
percentile.description: The EPSS score's percentile representing relative importance and ranking of the score in the larger EPSS dataset.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

score.caption: EPPS Score
score.description: The EPSS score representing the probability [0-1] of exploitation in the wild in the next 30 days (following score publication).

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the EPSS model used to calculate the score.

epss.caption: EPSS
epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).
epss.name: epss

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: Describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity that triggered the detection.

api.caption: API Details
api.description: Describes details about the API call associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

connection_info.caption: Connection Info
connection_info.description: Describes details about the network connection associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

container.caption: Container
container.description: Describes details about the container associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

data.caption: Data
data.description: Additional evidence data that is not accounted for in the specific evidence attributes. Use only when absolutely necessary.

database.caption: Database
database.description: Describes details about the database associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

databucket.caption: Databucket
databucket.description: Describes details about the databucket associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

device.caption: Device
device.description: An addressable device, computer system or host associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint
dst_endpoint.description: Describes details about the destination of the network activity that triggered the detection.

email.caption: Email
email.description: The email object associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

file.caption: File
file.description: Describes details about the file associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

http_request.caption: HTTP Request
http_request.description: Describes details about the http request associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

http_response.caption: HTTP Response
http_response.description: Describes details about the http response associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

ja4_fingerprint_list.caption: JA4+ Fingerprints
ja4_fingerprint_list.description: Describes details about the JA4+ fingerprints that triggered the detection.

job.caption: Job
job.description: Describes details about the scheduled job that was associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The naming convention or type identifier of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, the @odata.type from Microsoft Graph Alerts V2 or display_name from CrowdStrike Falcon Incident Behaviors.

process.caption: Process
process.description: Describes details about the process associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

query.caption: DNS Query
query.description: Describes details about the DNS query associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

reg_key.caption: Registry Key
reg_key.description: Describes details about the registry key that triggered the detection.

reg_value.caption: Registry Value
reg_value.description: Describes details about the registry value that triggered the detection.

resources.caption: Cloud Resources
resources.description: Describes details about the cloud resources directly related to activity that triggered the detection. For resources impacted by the detection, use Affected Resources at the top-level of the finding.

script.caption: Script
script.description: Describes details about the script that was associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

src_endpoint.caption: Source Endpoint
src_endpoint.description: Describes details about the source of the network activity that triggered the detection.

tls.caption: TLS
tls.description: Describes details about the Transport Layer Security (TLS) activity that triggered the detection.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, the activity_id from CrowdStrike Falcon Alerts or behavior_id from CrowdStrike Falcon Incident Behaviors.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

url.caption: URL
url.description: The URL object that pertains to the event or object associated to the activity that triggered the detection.

user.caption: User
user.description: Describes details about the user that was the target or somehow else associated with the activity that triggered the detection.

verdict.caption: Verdict
verdict.description: The normalized verdict of the evidence associated with the security detection.

verdict_id.caption: Verdict ID
verdict_id.description: The normalized verdict (or status) ID of the evidence associated with the security detection. For example, Microsoft Graph Security Alerts contain a verdict enumeration for each type of evidence associated with the Alert. This is typically set by an automated investigation process or an analyst/investigator assigned to the finding.

1.caption: False Positive
1.description: The verdict for the evidence has been identified as a False Positive.

10.caption: Duplicate
10.description: This evidence duplicates existing evidence related to this finding.

2.caption: True Positive
2.description: The verdict for the evidence has been identified as a True Positive.

3.caption: Disregard
3.description: The verdict for the evidence is that is should be Disregarded.

4.caption: Suspicious
4.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as Suspicious.

5.caption: Benign
5.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as Benign.

6.caption: Test
6.description: The evidence is part of a Test, or other sanctioned behavior(s).

7.caption: Insufficient Data
7.description: There is insufficient data to render a verdict on the evidence.

8.caption: Security Risk
8.description: The verdict for the evidence is that the behavior has been identified as a Security Risk.

9.caption: Managed Externally
9.description: The verdict for the evidence is Managed Externally, such as in a case management tool.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

win_service.caption: Windows Service
win_service.description: Describes details about the Windows service that triggered the detection.

evidences.caption: Windows Evidence Artifacts
evidences.description: Extends the evidences object to add Windows specific fields
evidences.name: evidences

name.description: The schema extension name. For example: dev.

raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The schema extension unique identifier. For example: 999.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The schema extension version. For example: 1.0.0-alpha.2.

extension.caption: Schema Extension
extension.description: The OCSF Schema Extension object provides detailed information about the schema extension used to construct the event. The schema extensions are registered in the extensions.md file.
extension.name: extension

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the feature.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the feature.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

feature.caption: Feature
feature.description: The Feature object provides information about the software product feature that generated a specific event. It encompasses details related to the capabilities, components, user interface (UI) design, and performance upgrades associated with the feature.
feature.name: feature

accessed_time.caption: Accessed Time
accessed_time.description: The time when the file was last accessed.

accessor.caption: Accessor
accessor.description: The name of the user who last accessed the object.

attributes.caption: Attributes
attributes.description: The bitmask value that represents the file attributes.

company_name.caption: Company Name
company_name.description: The name of the company that published the file. For example: Microsoft Corporation.

confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality
confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID
confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the file was created.

creator.caption: Creator
creator.description: The user that created the file.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the file, as returned by file system. For example: the description as returned by the Unix file command or the Windows file type.

drive_type.caption: Drive Type
drive_type.description: The drive type, normalized to the caption of the drive_type_id value. In the case of Other, it is defined by the source.

drive_type_id.caption: Drive Type ID
drive_type_id.description: Identifies the type of a disk drive, i.e. fixed, removable, etc.

1.caption: Removable
1.description: The drive has removable media; for example, a floppy drive, thumb drive, or flash card reader.

2.caption: Fixed
2.description: The drive has fixed media; for example, a hard disk drive or flash drive.

3.caption: Remote
3.description: The drive is a remote (network) drive.

4.caption: CD-ROM
4.description: The drive is a CD-ROM drive.

5.caption: RAM Disk
5.description: The drive is a RAM disk.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The drive type is not mapped. See the drive_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

encryption_details.caption: Encryption Details
encryption_details.description: The encryption details of the file. Should be populated if the file is encrypted.

ext.caption: File Extension
ext.description: The extension of the file, excluding the leading dot. For example: exe from svchost.exe, or gz from export.tar.gz.

internal_name.caption: Internal Name
internal_name.description: The name of the file as identified within the file itself. This contrasts with the name by which the file is known on disk. Where available, the internal name is widely used by security practitioners and detection content because the on-disk file name is not reliable. On the Windows OS, most PE files contain a VERSIONINFO resource from which the internal name can be obtained. On macOS, binaries can optionally embed a copy of the application's Info.plist file which in turn contains the name of the executable.

is_deleted.caption: Deleted
is_deleted.description: Indicates if the file was deleted from the filesystem.

is_encrypted.caption: Encrypted
is_encrypted.description: Indicates if the file is encrypted.

is_public.caption: Public
is_public.description: Indicates if the file is publicly accessible. For example in an object's public access in AWS S3

is_system.caption: System
is_system.description: The indication of whether the object is part of the operating system.

mime_type.caption: MIME type
mime_type.description: The Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) type of the file, if applicable.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the file was last modified.

modifier.caption: Modifier
modifier.description: The user that last modified the file.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the file. For example: svchost.exe

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The user that owns the file/object.

parent_folder.caption: Parent Folder
parent_folder.description: The parent folder in which the file resides. For example: c:\windows\system32

path.caption: Path
path.description: The full path to the file. For example: c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product that created or installed the file.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

signature.caption: Digital Signature
signature.description: The digital signature of the file.

size.caption: Size
size.description: The size of data, in bytes.

storage_class.caption: Storage Class
storage_class.description: The storage class of the file. For example in AWS S3: STANDARD, STANDARD_IA, GLACIER.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the file.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The file type.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the file as defined by the storage system, such the file system file ID.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

url.caption: URL
url.description: The URL of the file, when applicable.

xattributes.caption: Extended Attributes
xattributes.description:
An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs where each pair represents a file or folder extended attribute.

For example: Windows alternate data stream attributes (ADS stream name, ADS size, etc.), user-defined or application-defined attributes, ACL, owner, primary group, etc. Examples from DCS:

  • ads_name
  • ads_size
  • dacl
  • owner
  • primary_group
  • link_name - name of the link associated to the file.
  • hard_link_count - the number of links that are associated to the file.

file.caption: File
file.description: The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details.

filenames.description: The names a file is known by.

findings.description: The findings from threat intelligence platforms

fingerprints.description: An array of known fingerprints for the file.

first_seen_time.description: The initial detection time of the activity or object. See specific usage

last_seen_time.description: The most recent detection time of the activity or object. See specific usage.

reputations.description: Reputation score as reported by provider

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

vendor_name.description: The vendor that provided the intelligence.

file_intelligence.description: Insights from threat intelligence platforms about files

created_time.description: The time when the finding was created.

keyboard_layout.description: The keyboard locale identifier name (e.g., en-US).

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

keyboard_info.caption: Keyboard Information
keyboard_info.description: The Keyboard Information object contains details and attributes related to a computer or device keyboard. It encompasses information that describes the characteristics, capabilities, and configuration of the keyboard.
keyboard_info.name: keyboard_info

phase_id.caption: Kill Chain Phase ID
phase_id.description: The cyber kill chain phase identifier.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The kill chain phase is unknown.

1.caption: Reconnaissance
1.description: The attackers pick a target and perform a detailed analysis, start collecting information (email addresses, conferences information, etc.) and evaluate the victim’s vulnerabilities to determine how to exploit them.

2.caption: Weaponization
2.description: The attackers develop a malware weapon and aim to exploit the discovered vulnerabilities.

3.caption: Delivery
3.description: The intruders will use various tactics, such as phishing, infected USB drives, etc.

4.caption: Exploitation
4.description: The intruders start leveraging vulnerabilities to executed code on the victim’s system.

5.caption: Installation
5.description: The intruders install malware on the victim’s system.

6.caption: Command & Control
6.description: Malware opens a command channel to enable the intruders to remotely manipulate the victim's system.

7.caption: Actions on Objectives
7.description: With hands-on keyboard access, intruders accomplish the mission’s goal.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The kill chain phase is not mapped. See the phase attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

kill_chain_phase.caption: Kill Chain Phase
kill_chain_phase.description: The Kill Chain Phase object represents a single phase of a cyber attack, including the initial reconnaissance and planning stages up to the final objective of the attacker. It provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack. See Cyber Kill Chain®.
kill_chain_phase.name: kill_chain_phase

cost_center.caption: Cost Center
cost_center.description: The cost center associated with the user.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The timestamp when the user was created.

deleted_time.caption: Deleted Time
deleted_time.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.

email_addrs.caption: Email Addresses
email_addrs.description: A list of additional email addresses for the user.

employee_uid.caption: Employee ID
employee_uid.description: The employee identifier assigned to the user by the organization.

given_name.caption: Given Name
given_name.description: The given or first name of the user.

hire_time.caption: Hire Time
hire_time.description: The timestamp when the user was or will be hired by the organization.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The labels associated with the user. For example in AD this could be the userType, employeeType. For example: Member, Employee.

last_login_time.caption: Last Login
last_login_time.description: The last time when the user logged in.

ldap_cn.caption: LDAP Common Name
ldap_cn.description: The LDAP and X.500 commonName attribute, typically the full name of the person. For example, John Doe.

ldap_dn.caption: LDAP Distinguished Name
ldap_dn.description: The X.500 Distinguished Name (DN) is a structured string that uniquely identifies an entry, such as a user, in an X.500 directory service For example, cn=John Doe,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com.

leave_time.caption: Leave Time
leave_time.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location associated with a user. This is typically the user's usual work location.

manager.caption: Manager
manager.description: The user's manager. This helps in understanding an org hierarchy. This should only ever be populated once in an event. I.e. there should not be a manager's manager in an event.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.

office_location.caption: Office Location
office_location.description: The primary office location associated with the user. This could be any string and isn't a specific address. For example, South East Virtual.

phone_number.caption: Telephone Number
phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user. Corresponds to the LDAP Telephone-Number CN.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

surname.caption: Surname
surname.description: The last or family name for the user.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the user.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

ldap_person.caption: LDAP Person
ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.
ldap_person.name: ldap_person

classification.caption: Classification
classification.description: The request classification as defined by the load balancer.

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: The numeric response status code detailing the connection from the load balancer to the destination target.

dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint
dst_endpoint.description: The destination to which the load balancer is distributing traffic.

endpoint_connections.caption: Endpoint Connections
endpoint_connections.description: An object detailing the load balancer connection attempts and responses.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address of the load balancer node that handled the client request. Note: the load balancer may have other IP addresses, and this is not an IP address of the target/distribution endpoint - see dst_endpoint.

message.caption: Message
message.description: The load balancer message.

metrics.caption: Metrics
metrics.description: General purpose metrics associated with the load balancer.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the load balancer.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

status_detail.caption: Status Detail
status_detail.description: The status detail contains additional status information about the load balancer distribution event.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier for the load balancer.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

load_balancer.caption: Load Balancer
load_balancer.description: The load balancer object describes the load balancer entity and contains additional information regarding the distribution of traffic across a network.
load_balancer.name: load_balancer

aerial_height.caption: Aerial Height
aerial_height.description: Expressed as either height above takeoff location or height above ground level (AGL) for a UAS current location. This value is provided in meters and must have a minimum resolution of 1 m. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: -1000 m.

coordinates.caption: Coordinates
coordinates.description: A two-element array, containing a longitude/latitude pair. The format conforms with GeoJSON. For example: [-73.983, 40.719].

country.caption: Country
country.description:
The ISO 3166-1 Alpha-2 country code.

Note: The two letter country code should be capitalized. For example: US or CA.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the geographical location.

geodetic_altitude.caption: Geodetic Altitude
geodetic_altitude.description: The aircraft distance above or below the ellipsoid as measured along a line that passes through the aircraft and is normal to the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid. This value is provided in meters and must have a minimum resolution of 1 m. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: -1000 m.

geodetic_vertical_accuracy.caption: Geodetic Vertical Accuracy
geodetic_vertical_accuracy.description: Provides quality/containment on geodetic altitude. This is based on ADS-B Geodetic Vertical Accuracy (GVA). Measured in meters.

geohash.caption: Geohash
geohash.description:
Geohash of the geo-coordinates (latitude and longitude).

Geohashing is a geocoding system used to encode geographic coordinates in decimal degrees, to a single string.

horizontal_accuracy.caption: Horizontal Accuracy
horizontal_accuracy.description: Provides quality/containment on horizontal position. This is based on ADS-B NACp. Measured in meters.

is_on_premises.caption: On Premises
is_on_premises.description: The indication of whether the location is on premises.

isp.caption: ISP
isp.description: The name of the Internet Service Provider (ISP).

lat.caption: Latitude
lat.description: The geographical Latitude coordinate represented in Decimal Degrees (DD). For example: 42.361145.

long.caption: Longitude
long.description: The geographical Longitude coordinate represented in Decimal Degrees (DD). For example: -71.057083.

postal_code.caption: Postal Code
postal_code.description: The postal code of the location.

pressure_altitude.caption: Pressure Altitude
pressure_altitude.description: The uncorrected barometric pressure altitude (based on reference standard 29.92 inHg, 1013.25 mb) provides a reference for algorithms that utilize 'altitude deltas' between aircraft. This value is provided in meters and must have a minimum resolution of 1 m.. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: -1000 m.

provider.caption: Provider
provider.description: The provider of the geographical location data.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

region.caption: Region
region.description: The alphanumeric code that identifies the principal subdivision (e.g. province or state) of the country. For example, 'CH-VD' for the Canton of Vaud, Switzerland

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The Geo Location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address.
location.name: location

device.caption: Device
device.description: The device where the events are logged.

event_uid.caption: Event UID
event_uid.description: The unique identifier of the event assigned by the logger.

log_level.caption: Log Level
log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.

log_name.caption: Log Name
log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.

log_provider.caption: Log Provider
log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.

log_version.caption: Log Version
log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.

logged_time.caption: Logged Time
logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the logging product instance.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product logging the event.  This may be the event source product, a management server product, a scanning product, a SIEM, etc.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

transmit_time.caption: Transmission Time
transmit_time.description: The time when the event was transmitted from the logging device to it's next destination.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the logging product instance.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the logging product.

logger.caption: Logger
logger.description: The Logger object represents the device and product where events are stored with times for receipt and transmission.  This may be at the source device where the event occurred, a remote scanning device, intermediate hops, or the ultimate destination.
logger.name: logger

is_truncated.caption: Is Truncated
is_truncated.description: Indicates that value has been truncated. May be omitted if truncation has not occurred.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

untruncated_size.caption: Untruncated Size
untruncated_size.description: The size in bytes of the string represented by value before truncation. Should be omitted if truncation has not occurred.

value.caption: Value
value.description: The string value, truncated if is_truncated is true.

long_string.caption: Long String
long_string.description: This object is a used to capture strings which may be truncated by a security product due to their length.
long_string.name: long_string

classification_ids.caption: Classification IDs
classification_ids.description: The list of normalized identifiers of the malware classifications. Reference: STIX Malware Types

99.caption: Other
99.description: The classification is not mapped. See the classifications attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

classifications.caption: Classifications
classifications.description: The list of malware classifications, normalized to the captions of the classification_ids values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.

cves.caption: CVE List
cves.description: List of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE).

name.caption: Name
name.description: The malware name, as reported by the detection engine.

path.caption: Path
path.description: The filesystem path of the malware that was observed.

provider.caption: Provider
provider.description: The provider of the malware information.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The malware unique identifier, as reported by the detection engine. For example a virus id or an IPS signature id.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

malware.caption: Malware
malware.description: The Malware object describes the classification of known malicious software, which is intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.
malware.name: malware

data.caption: Data
data.description: The managed entity content as a JSON object.

device.caption: Device
device.description: An addressable device, computer system or host.

group.caption: Group
group.description: The group object associated with an entity such as user, policy, or rule.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The detailed geographical location usually associated with an IP address.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the managed entity.

org.caption: Organization
org.description: Organization and org unit relevant to the event or object.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description: Describes details of a managed policy.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The managed entity type. For example: policy, user, organizational unit, device.

type_id.caption: Type ID
type_id.description: The type of the Managed Entity. It is recommended to also populate the type attribute with the associated label, or the source specific name if Other.

1.caption: Device
1.description: A managed Device entity. This item corresponds to population of the device attribute.

2.caption: User
2.description: A managed User entity. This item corresponds to population of the user attribute.

3.caption: Group
3.description: A managed Group entity. This item corresponds to population of the group attribute.

4.caption: Organization
4.description: A managed Organization entity. This item corresponds to population of the org attribute.

5.caption: Policy
5.description: A managed Policy entity. This item corresponds to population of the policy attribute.

6.caption: Email
6.description: A managed Email entity. This item corresponds to population of the email attribute.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The identifier of the managed entity.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

user.caption: User
user.description: The user that pertains to the event or object.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the managed entity. For example: 1.2.3.

managed_entity.caption: Managed Entity
managed_entity.description: The Managed Entity object describes the type and version of an entity, such as a user, device, or policy. For types in the type_id enum list, an associated attribute should be populated. If the type of entity is not in the type_id list, information can be put into the data attribute and the type attribute should identify the entity.
managed_entity.name: managed_entity

correlation_uid.caption: Correlation UID
correlation_uid.description: The unique identifier used to correlate events.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

debug.caption: Debug Information
debug.description: Debug information about non-fatal issues with this OCSF event. Each issue is a line in this string array.

event_code.caption: Event Code
event_code.description: The Event ID, Code, or Name that the product uses to primarily identify the event.

extension.caption: Schema Extension
extension.description: The schema extension used to create the event.

extensions.caption: Schema Extensions
extensions.description: The schema extensions used to create the event.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels attached to the event. For example: ["sample", "dev"]

log_level.caption: Log Level
log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.

log_name.caption: Log Name
log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.

log_provider.caption: Log Provider
log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.

log_version.caption: Log Version
log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.

logged_time.caption: Logged Time
logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

loggers.caption: Loggers
loggers.description: An array of Logger objects that describe the devices and logging products between the event source and its eventual destination. Note, this attribute can be used when there is a complex end-to-end path of event flow.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.

original_time.caption: Original Time
original_time.description: The original event time as reported by the event source. For example, the time in the original format from system event log such as Syslog on Unix/Linux and the System event file on Windows. Omit if event is generated instead of collected via logs.

processed_time.caption: Processed Time
processed_time.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product that reported the event.

profiles.caption: Profiles
profiles.description: The list of profiles used to create the event. Profiles should be referenced by their name attribute for core profiles, or extension/name for profiles from extensions.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

sequence.caption: Sequence Number
sequence.description: Sequence number of the event. The sequence number is a value available in some events, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the event time precision.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the event.

uid.caption: Event UID
uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The Metadata object describes the metadata associated with the event.
metadata.name: metadata

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the metric.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

metric.caption: Metric
metric.description: The Metric object defines a simple name/value pair entity for a metric.
metric.name: metric

base_address.caption: Base Address
base_address.description: The memory address where the module was loaded.

file.caption: File
file.description: The module file object.

function_name.caption: Function Name
function_name.description: The entry-point function of the module. The system calls the entry-point function whenever a process or thread loads or unloads the module.

load_type.caption: Load Type
load_type.description: The load type, normalized to the caption of the load_type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

load_type_id.caption: Load Type ID
load_type_id.description: The normalized identifier for how the module was loaded in memory.

1.caption: Standard
1.description: A normal module loaded by the normal windows loading mechanism i.e. LoadLibrary.

2.caption: Non Standard
2.description: A module loaded in a way avoidant of normal windows procedures. i.e. Bootstrapped Loading/Manual Dll Loading.

3.caption: ShellCode
3.description: A raw module in process memory that is READWRITE_EXECUTE and had a thread started in its range.

4.caption: Mapped
4.description: A memory mapped file, typically created with CreatefileMapping/MapViewOfFile.

5.caption: NonStandard Backed
5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The load type is not mapped. See the load_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

start_address.caption: Start Address
start_address.description: The start address of the execution.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The module type.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

module.caption: Module
module.description: The Module object describes the load attributes of a module.
module.name: module

boundary.caption: Boundary
boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID
boundary_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

1.caption: Localhost
1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

10.caption: Gateway VPC
10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

11.caption: Internet Gateway
11.description: Through an Internet gateway (Nitro-based instances only)

2.caption: Internal
2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

3.caption: External
3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.

4.caption: Same VPC
4.description: Through another resource in the same VPC

5.caption: Internet/VPC Gateway
5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway
6.description: Through a virtual private gateway

7.caption: Intra-region VPC
7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.caption: Inter-region VPC
8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

9.caption: Local Gateway
9.description: Through a local gateway

99.caption: Other
99.description: The boundary is not mapped. See the boundary attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

community_uid.caption: Community ID
community_uid.description: The Community ID of the network connection.

direction.caption: Direction
direction.description: The direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

direction_id.caption: Direction ID
direction_id.description: The normalized identifier of the direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email.

1.caption: Inbound
1.description: Inbound network connection. The connection was originated from the Internet or outside network, destined for services on the inside network.

2.caption: Outbound
2.description: Outbound network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the Internet or outside network.

3.caption: Lateral
3.description: Lateral network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the inside network.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The direction is not mapped. See the direction attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

flag_history.caption: Connection Flag History
flag_history.description: The Connection Flag History summarizes events in a network connection. For example flags ShAD representing SYN, SYN/ACK, ACK and Data exchange.

protocol_name.caption: Protocol Name
protocol_name.description: The IP protocol name in lowercase, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: tcp or udp.

protocol_num.caption: Protocol Number
protocol_num.description: The IP protocol number, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: 6 for TCP and 17 for UDP.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The protocol version is not mapped. See the protocol_ver attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

session.caption: Session
session.description: The authenticated user or service session.

tcp_flags.caption: TCP Flags
tcp_flags.description: The network connection TCP header flags (i.e., control bits).

uid.caption: Connection UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

network_connection_info.caption: Network Connection Information
network_connection_info.description: The Network Connection Information object describes characteristics of an OSI Transport Layer communication, including TCP and UDP.
network_connection_info.name: network_connection_info

agent_list.caption: Agent List
agent_list.description: A list of agent objects associated with a device, endpoint, or resource.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: The Autonomous System details associated with an IP address.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

domain.caption: Domain
domain.description: The name of the domain that the endpoint belongs to or that corresponds to the endpoint.

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

instance_uid.caption: Instance ID
instance_uid.description: The unique identifier of a VM instance.

interface_name.caption: Network Interface Name
interface_name.description: The name of the network interface (e.g. eth2).

interface_uid.caption: Network Interface ID
interface_uid.description: The unique identifier of the network interface.

intermediate_ips.caption: Intermediate IP Addresses
intermediate_ips.description: The intermediate IP Addresses. For example, the IP addresses in the HTTP X-Forwarded-For header.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

ip_intelligence.caption: IP Intelligence
ip_intelligence.description: Insights from threat intelligence platforms about IP Address

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

mac.caption: MAC Address
mac.description: The Media Access Control (MAC) address of the endpoint.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

namespace_pid.caption: Namespace PID
namespace_pid.description: If running under a process namespace (such as in a container), the process identifier within that process namespace.

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the endpoint or was last logged into it.

port.caption: Port
port.description: The port used for communication within the network connection.

proxy_endpoint.caption: Proxy Endpoint
proxy_endpoint.description: The network proxy information pertaining to a specific endpoint. This can be used to describe information pertaining to network address translation (NAT).

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

subnet_uid.caption: Subnet UID
subnet_uid.description: The unique identifier of a virtual subnet.

svc_name.caption: Service Name
svc_name.description: The service name in service-to-service connections. For example, AWS VPC logs the pkt-src-aws-service and pkt-dst-aws-service fields identify the connection is coming from or going to an AWS service.

type.caption: Type

object.caption: Object
object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
object.name: object

name.caption: Name
name.description: The full name of the observable attribute. The name is a pointer/reference to an attribute within the OCSF event data. For example: file.name.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

reputation.caption: Reputation Scores
reputation.description: Contains the original and normalized reputation scores.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The observable value type name.

1.caption: Hostname
1.description:
Unique name assigned to a device connected to a computer network. It may be a fully qualified domain name (FQDN). For example:
r2-d2.example.com.,
mx.example.com

10.caption: Resource UID
10.description: Resource unique identifier. For example, S3 Bucket name or EC2 Instance ID.

11.caption: Port
11.description:
The TCP/UDP port number. For example:
80,
22.

12.caption: Subnet
12.description:
The subnet represented in a CIDR notation, using the format network_address/prefix_length. The network_address can be in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. The prefix length indicates the number of bits used for the network portion, and the remaining bits are available for host addresses within that subnet. For example:
192.168.1.0/24,
2001:0db8:85a3:0000::/64

13.caption: Command Line
13.description: The full command line used to launch an application, service, process, or job. For example: ssh user@10.0.0.10. If the command line is unavailable or missing, the empty string '' is to be used.

14.caption: Country
14.description:
The ISO 3166-1 Alpha-2 country code.

Note: The two letter country code should be capitalized. For example: US or CA.

15.caption: Process ID
15.description: The process identifier, as reported by the operating system. Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

16.caption: HTTP User-Agent
16.description: The request header that identifies the operating system and web browser.

17.caption: CWE ID
17.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration unique number assigned to a specific weakness. A CWE Identifier begins "CWE" followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CWE-123.

18.caption: CVE ID
18.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.

19.caption: User Credential ID
19.description: The unique identifier of the user's credential. For example, AWS Access Key ID.

2.caption: IP Address
2.description:
Internet Protocol address (IP address), in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. For example:
192.168.200.24,
2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334.

20.caption: Endpoint
20.description: The Endpoint object describes a physical or virtual device that connects to and exchanges information with a computer network. Some examples of endpoints are mobile devices, desktop computers, virtual machines, embedded devices, and servers. Internet-of-Things devices—like cameras, lighting, refrigerators, security systems, smart speakers, and thermostats—are also endpoints.

21.caption: User
21.description: The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal.

22.caption: Email
22.description: The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction, and can include embedded URLs and files.

23.caption: Uniform Resource Locator
23.description: The Uniform Resource Locator (URL) object describes the characteristics of a URL.

24.caption: File
24.description: The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details.

25.caption: Process
25.description: The Process object describes a running instance of a launched program.

26.caption: Geo Location
26.description: The Geo Location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address.

27.caption: Container
27.description: The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

28.caption: Registry Key
28.description: The registry key object describes a Windows registry key.

29.caption: Registry Value
29.description: The registry value object describes a Windows registry value.

3.caption: MAC Address
3.description:
Media Access Control (MAC) address. For example:
18:36:F3:98:4F:9A.

30.caption: Fingerprint
30.description: The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.

31.caption: User Object: uid
31.description: The unique user identifier. For example, the Windows user SID, ActiveDirectory DN or AWS user ARN.

33.caption: Group Object: uid
33.description: The unique identifier of the group. For example, for Windows events this is the security identifier (SID) of the group.

34.caption: Account Object: name
34.description: The name of the account (e.g. GCP Project name , Linux Account name or AWS Account name).

35.caption: Account Object: uid
35.description: The unique identifier of the account (e.g. AWS Account ID , OCID , GCP Project ID , Azure Subscription ID , Google Workspace Customer ID , or M365 Tenant UID).

36.caption: Script Content
36.description: The script content, normalized to UTF-8 encoding irrespective of its original encoding. When emitting this attribute, it may be appropriate to truncate large scripts. When consuming this attribute, large scripts should be anticipated.

37.caption: Serial Number
37.description: The serial number that pertains to the object. See specific usage.

4.caption: User Name
4.description:
User name. For example:
john_doe.

5.caption: Email Address
5.description:
Email address. For example:
john_doe@example.com.

6.caption: URL String
6.description:
Uniform Resource Locator (URL) string. For example:
http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe.

7.caption: File Name
7.description:
File name. For example:
text-file.txt.

8.caption: Hash
8.description:
Hash. A unique value that corresponds to the content of the file, image, ja3_hash or hassh found in the schema. For example:
MD5: 3172ac7e2b55cbb81f04a6e65855a628.

9.caption: Process Name
9.description:
Process name. For example:
Notepad.

unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

value.caption: Value
value.description:
The value associated with the observable attribute. The meaning of the value depends on the observable type.
If the name refers to a scalar attribute, then the value is the value of the attribute.
If the name refers to an object attribute, then the value is not populated.

observable.description: The observable object is a pivot element that contains related information found in many places in the event.

end_line.caption: End Line
end_line.description: The line number of the last line of the file, where the information was discovered.

page_number.caption: Page Number
page_number.description: The page number in a document, where the information was discovered.

raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

row_number.caption: Row Number
row_number.description: The row number in a spreadsheet, where the information was discovered.

start_line.caption: Start Line
start_line.description: The line number of the first line of the file, where the information was discovered.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

occurrence_details.caption: Occurrence Details
occurrence_details.description: Details about where in the target entity, specified information was discovered. Only the attributes, relevant to the target entity type should be populuated.
occurrence_details.name: occurrence_details

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the organization, Oracle Cloud Tenancy, Google Cloud Organization, or AWS Organization. For example, Widget, Inc. or the AWS Organization name .

ou_name.caption: Org Unit Name
ou_name.description: The name of an organizational unit, Google Cloud Folder, or AWS Org Unit. For example, the GCP Project Name , or Dev_Prod_OU .

ou_uid.caption: Org Unit ID
ou_uid.description: The unique identifier of an organizational unit, Google Cloud Folder, or AWS Org Unit. For example, an Oracle Cloud Tenancy ID , AWS OU ID , or GCP Folder ID .

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The event data as received from the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the organization, Oracle Cloud Tenancy, Google Cloud Organization, or AWS Organization. For example, an AWS Org ID or Oracle Cloud Domain ID .
